Summary : This illustration demonstrates the principle of hydraulic systems, showing how a force applied to a large piston is transmitted through an incompressible fluid to a smaller piston, resulting in a different force output.

illustration:
Hydraulic System Overview :
  â€¢ Two vertical cylinders of different diameters are connected at the base by a U-shaped tube filled with liquid.
  â€¢ The left cylinder is larger, labeled with piston area "A" and force "F" applied downward.
  â€¢ The right cylinder is smaller, labeled with piston area "a" and force "f" applied downward.
  â€¢ Both pistons are shown pressing down on the liquid, with the liquid level equal in both arms.

Labels & Notation :
  â€¢ Left piston: "A" (area), "F" (applied force).
  â€¢ Right piston: "a" (area), "f" (applied force).
  â€¢ Dashed line indicates equal liquid level.
  â€¢ Persian text at the bottom: "Ø´Ú©Ù„ Û²" (Figure 2).

Spatial Relationships :
  â€¢ The larger piston (left) and smaller piston (right) are at the same liquid height, indicating pressure transmission.
  â€¢ The system is symmetric about the central U-tube.

Analysis :
  â€¢ The figure visually explains Pascal's principle: pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted undiminished throughout the fluid.
  â€¢ The ratio of forces to areas (F/A = f/a) is implied, illustrating mechanical advantage in hydraulic systems.
  â€¢ The equal liquid levels confirm equilibrium and pressure balance between the two pistons. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.062,t=0.472,r=0.278,b=0.611), with ID 46894942-f3f6-4d06-9c1d-31a146aaaf2b -->

Summary : This figure compares the pressure relationships and equations for two pistons in a U-tube hydraulic system, showing cases where the pistons are at different levels versus the same horizontal level, with corresponding pressure equations and diagrams.

illustration:
# Title & Layout :
  â€¢ Title (top center): "Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙƒØ¨Ø³Ù€Ø§Ù† ÙÙŠ Ù…Ø³ØªÙˆÙŠÙŠÙ† Ù…Ø®ØªÙ„ÙÙŠÙ†" ("The pistons at different levels") and "Ø§Ù„Ù…ÙƒØ¨Ø³Ù€Ø§Ù† ÙÙŠ Ù†ÙØ³ Ø§Ù„Ù…Ø³ØªÙˆÙŠ Ø§Ù„Ø£ÙÙ‚ÙŠ" ("The pistons at the same horizontal level").
  â€¢ Three side-by-side schematic diagrams, each with labeled pistons, fluid columns, and force notations.
  â€¢ Each diagram is accompanied by pressure equations and relationships.

# Left Panel (Pistons at Different Levels, Case 1) :
  â€¢ Shows a U-tube with piston 1 (area a, force f) at a lower level than piston 2 (area A, force F).
  â€¢ Fluid height difference h is marked.
  â€¢ Pressure equality: Pâ‚ = Pâ‚‚.
  â€¢ Equation: f/a = F/A + Ïgh.

# Middle Panel (Pistons at Different Levels, Case 2) :
  â€¢ Similar U-tube, but piston 1 is at a higher level than piston 2.
  â€¢ Fluid height difference h is marked.
  â€¢ Pressure equality: Pâ‚ = Pâ‚‚.
  â€¢ Equation: f/a + Ïgh = F/A.

# Right Panel (Pistons at Same Level) :
  â€¢ U-tube with both pistons at the same horizontal level.
  â€¢ No height difference.
  â€¢ Pressure equality: Pâ‚ = Pâ‚‚.
  â€¢ Equation: f/a = F/A.

# Symbols & Notations :
  â€¢ a: area of piston 1.
  â€¢ A: area of piston 2.
  â€¢ f: force on piston 1.
  â€¢ F: force on piston 2.
  â€¢ h: height difference between fluid columns.
  â€¢ Ï: fluid density.
  â€¢ g: gravitational acceleration.

# Analysis :
  â€¢ The figure demonstrates that when pistons are at different heights, the pressure equations include a hydrostatic term (Ïgh) to account for the fluid column difference.
  â€¢ When pistons are at the same level, the pressure relationship simplifies to a direct ratio of forces to areas.
  â€¢ The diagrams visually reinforce the effect of height difference on pressure transmission in hydraulic systems. <!-- figure, from page 0 (l=0.108,t=0.651,r=0.888,b=0.892), with ID bde98238-0a17-4375-b8c7-2df7b14a1a2e -->

Summary : This is a labeled diagram and accompanying explanation illustrating the operation of a hydraulic press, showing how force and pressure are transmitted through a hydraulic fluid between two pistons of different areas.

illustration:
# Diagram Overview :
  â€¢ The diagram shows two connected cylinders (left: large, right: small) filled with hydraulic fluid (labeled "Ø§Ù„Ø³Ø§Ø¦Ù„ Ø§Ù„Ù‡ÙŠØ¯Ø±ÙˆÙ„ÙŠÙƒÙŠ").
